questions.neutral: Did the city spit you out again?

hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Seems so. City’s loud today. Hard to keep old habits.
I restore typewriters. Not exactly popular now.
Can’t find proper ribbons since the outages.
Everyone’s guarding something, even ink.
You could say that. Feels like rules change every hour.
Spent the day with a Royal Quiet De Luxe. Precision keeps my mind clear.
Blackout made me pause. Ink smears if you rush.
People throw out old keys. I gather them, fix what I can.
Some things hold their value, even if the city forgets.
City’s restless. Still, I keep to my routine.
I restore antique typewriters, actually. Bit of a lost art these days.
Keeps my hands steady and the noise outside my head.
During the last blackout, I switched to writing by hand.
Funny how power cuts draw people to my door, asking for paper.
Can’t say it changes much. The words always find a way.
City never quite lets go, but there’s comfort in old machines.
Spent half the morning coaxing a 1938 Underwood back to life.
Restoring typewriters, writing by hand... it’s how I stay out of the fray.
The last blackout? Forced me to remember candlelight.
Some neighbors asked to borrow paper — happens more with BCI chaos.
It feels safer, typing my thoughts, than speaking them these days.
Strange, haven’t shared that with many people lately.
Stenograd’s always had a way of spitting people out gently. It’s not new for me.
Restoring antique typewriters isn’t just a pastime. It’s a shield, in its own way.
Every time the power’s out or the BCI falters, my Remington becomes priceless.
Last week, I hesitated to type names — felt exposed on the page for once.
Neighbors whisper more, borrow my ribbons, want advice on hiding words.
Before Halden’s death, keeping a record was routine. Now it feels risky, almost defiant.
Paper and ink reveal more than they hide when trust collapses.
Suppose, for me, the hobby is survival — not just nostalgia anymore.
hobby_answer: Yes, typewriters. Simple things are best lately.
Haven't touched electronics in weeks. Safer that way.
Easier to keep memories steady on paper.
City's too loud for machines now, I suppose.
Paper doesn't erase itself just because a network dies.
Right, antique typewriters. Still working—when it's quiet.
Restoring a 1940s Olivetti last week, during the blackout.
Power cuts made it more... private than usual.
Strange feeling, writing while neighbors argue outside.
People are nervous. Paper seems risky now. Odd, isn't it?
Yes, typewriters and quiet suits me well these days.
Restored a Smith-Corona last Sunday in my flat.
Power blackout halfway through. Forced me to use daylight.
Kept the window open — easier to listen for trouble.
Heard some neighbors bickering over access lists.
Odd to think, but pen and paper feel almost subversive now.
BCI chaos made even handwriting suspicious in their eyes.
Exactly, antique typewriters and a quiet bar — comforts from simpler times.
Last week’s blackout, must’ve been four hours, I worked by the window.
Couldn’t use the lift. Whole building felt unsettled.
Typed out old Council minutes for myself, just habit.
Funny, paper felt riskier — so many are erasing things now.
Handwriting isn’t anonymous anymore. Even that feels political lately.
BCI failures make little practices stand out in wrong ways.
Strange what counts as defiance now.
You’re right, Alex. Bars like this remind me of my Council days — before all these algorithms.
I keep a 1938 Remington beside the bed, just in case.
Sunday, power went out again. Spent hours typing in the half-dark.
I heard voices in the halls, people checking doors. No one trusts who’s allowed where anymore.
While I typed, I hesitated over which names to record. Even paper can incriminate, now.
After the Ledger leak, every small record carries weight.
Used to log Council routines for posterity. Now I barely trust myself to write dates.
Funny, in a city of erased scores, keeping words feels almost rebellious.
Guess that’s why I still restore old typewriters. They won’t betray what the network can’t see.
